author: hatemydarnjob
body:
OP here.

This came from an array of trades. Never bear or bull. Aways trying to time a pull back or a rip up with weekly options. All positions are from a lot of different shit. Amd, Tesla fb aapl FedEx ups, whatever you heard of, I traded it. Was on the right side a lot of the time, never with the right capital. Every time I sized up, I was on the wrong side.

Entirely gambling weeklies. This is for all the newbies who think it’s a “get rich quick scheme” from seeing the recent gain porn. Those people are literally 5-10 people of 9 million of us.

Not saying don’t trade options, just be careful.

Also, I’m a full on degenerate bastard. I bet 20-30-40k on combat sports at a time. Play with shit you can lose, please. I hate to see post with

“Lost my life savings and don’t know what to do”

Started a new account for 2021, will update you fellas in 6 months.

GOOOOOD LUCK.

author: MajorDiamondHands
body: I’ve been trading since 2015. I’ve seen Amazon <500$, Netflix <100$, Tesla at <180$. I will hold my gme shares for sure! When I have learned on thing it is that patience pays off. Just relax and let it grow, don’t worry about short term up and downs. I once was in amd and that was a crazy ride. If I would have just held it it would have paid off big time. Lesson learned. Just hold, be calm, emotions will go high and low, let them pass by like clouds in the sky. That’s the way you’ll make big tendies in this game. Did you see how everyone got excited today at the rocket fuel phase? Guess what our goal is way higher than that and it will naturally climb up higher again. We don’t need hype. This thing will be driven by the share buy backs alone. It will be beautiful

author: Roirrawa
body:
My man. I'm 35 and I've failed a lot. I worked shit retail sales. Banking and tech companies during my short life. I tried to start businesses throughout that time amd failed many times. Bad timing, bad strategy, bad partners. You name it. Right now I run a marketing firm and we cleared 5m rev this year. 
You're only failing if you don't learn something from it. 
You're young. You have time to learn and grow.

author: SasquatchTitties
body:
I agree.

People here keep brining up the "value" of the company while completely overlooking what is actually happening in the marketplace. Between the limit on buying stocks and hedge funds trading between themselves to drive the price down, and creating a distraction (SLV) to draw attention and fill pockets, this should be throwing off a significantly larger red flag than "ERMERGERD WSB SAYS GME WORTH $69,420 LOOL". Who gives a shit, you're completely missing the point here. Short sellers expose themselves to basically unlimited risk. But that risk never actually materializes for them because they can just cheat the system. Meanwhile someone can go buy a stock and lose value because of *their* game OR someone can go short a stock and become insolvent while the *big boys on WallStreet* walk away.

GME isn't an isolated incident. BB, NOK, AMC and a number of others are getting hammered- and have been getting hammered since last Wednesday because the people on the losing side don't want to lose at the game they created for themselves. BB basically experienced a rug pull- it didn't taper off or settle in the 20's... it looks like someone pulled a plug. Look at what happened a month ago (or more) with PLTR and Shitron. Tesla, Microsoft, Apple, Nvidia... AMD have all been recent targets of this institutional wide short selling.

body: I was a believer until today. It seems every time the spike is supposed to happen, the price tanks and the goalposts get moved. More and more evidence says that shorts have covered, and, even if there is some fuckery afoot, you have to realize that this much smoke usually signals a fire. I've learned a lot from this, and I now know how to invest (not in meme stocks, but in legit good companies like AMD). I got in at $80, so I've made a decent amount of money too. If this thing blasts off and I'm wrong, oh well.

author: curioustrader86
body:
BB has been developing a solid business in EVs, AI and Cybersecurity. They have solved the patent issue with FB. Partnering with AWS in their IVY products. QNX is being utilized by almost all major automakers.

The stock will easily surge back to the last week's highs. The close below $15 on Friday was artificial, the market makers forced BB to stay below $15 mark and brokers limited the stock's purchase. Otherwise BB was going to break $30.

Load BB while it's massively discounted below $20, it'll take off just like AMD did. BB is a great long term play and will most probably close the year around $60-80.

author: adjustable_beard
body: Why good? AMD doesn't have their own fabs. Intel does. This will more immediately help intel over AMD

author: korbnala
body:
I actually work for a VAR/Reseller right now, and while it's true that hardware isn't the goldmine (all the margin is in software and accessories - but basically Software/SAAS) - there is *plenty* of margin in hardware - not to mention, the service charge for pre-building said gaming PC's. GME could theoretically score 8-15 points of margin on customized hardware, and still be selling at a discount.

If they score some partnerships with say, NVIDIA or AMD, that just helps the profit even further, if they are selling at a high enough rate. Companies tend to give 5-10 extra points discounting to their sellers if their order stream is consistent and high enough.

I like the stock at $50, I think it's a steal, but I don't think there is any one silver bullet here.

author: GushingGranny1
body:
*\*\*\*Disclosure: I have roughly $30,000 invested in AMD so my opinion might be biased.* 

Personally, I think it is a great time if any to invest in AMD. Main reason why is that recently the stock saw a dip from the 100 down to the mid 80s level mostly due to hedge funds deleveraging because of the whole GME fiasco so you are buying it at a discount in my opinion. 

Another reason why is that AMD is a classic turnaround story. It wasn't too long ago that the company was on the verge of bankruptcy due to failing product lines, but now it has CPUs that can rival and even outperform Intel and the specs for their GPUs shows they can actually go foot to foot with Nvidia. 

Also, keep in mind that the market for CPUs and GPUs are still growing so I don't really expect a deceleration of the company's revenue growth. 

Lastly, keep in mind that the Gov is still doing QE infinity, that and the trillions of stimulus they are gonna give out this year means it is a perfect environment for risk assets, so don't overthink it.

author: BasementPleb
body: Elon made Vlad poopy his pants. My counter argument to the clearinghouse argument, and what I deem the smoking gun of this situation. Why was AMD within the restricted stocks last week. Yes, AMD. ADVANCED. MICRO. DEVICES. It just so happened the short volume DOUBLED within the last few weeks before earnings and it’s close to 80% institution owned. It tanked after RH put it in the sell only list. And by no means is it even a “meme stock.” If that doesn’t smell like a steaming pile of fish, idk what is.

author: yoyoyaca
body: I like AMD. But I do want to clarify one thing that may or may not change your opinion. AMD does not make semiconductors. They *design* chips and outsource the semiconductors to foundries, like TSMC. There are a lot of steps and players involved with going from semiconductors to chips. Seeking alpha has a good article on it.

author: MarketBasketShopper
body:
Been following on and off for a couple years Buddy. And yes, piling in with your life savings just because it's been hyped is even more retarded than what this sub is supposed to be. This is supposed to be doing your own retarded DD on like AMD and stuff. People do YOLOs but they do them based on real work (often dumb work but still real work). And then the commenters don't praise them, they attack them. They abuse them, calling them retards, morons, autists. Because they did something frickin' dumb!

With the huge influx of people, this isn't WSB anymore, it's just a big circlejerk. And it's dumber than anything to YOLO your life savings on a circlejerk. It's not even fun or interesting when you lose.

author: TJGaming5_
body:
(Don't have enough karma to post so)

FORGET HOLD; instead, BUY THE DIP. Here's why:

GameStop just went through a massive undershoot and it's about to cycle back up or at least reach equilibrium with higher potential growth. 

Back in October, Microsoft announced a partnership with GameStop (this is important because of the XBOX market as prices for consoles start to return to normal with increased production of both the units and competitive GPUs by AMD and NVIDIA. 

Then there's GME's new executive appointments with a Chief Officer from Amazon AWS; this is in addition to their campaign for an E-Commerce transformation. 

And now onto technicals of the stock, Robinhood's class action lawsuits are coming together, short position volume is dying out, and we just saw the first green moves after that corrupt scam by Wall Street. 

Talking about indicators, RSI is low as hell, Schaff is on the verge of breaking 25, Ichimoku and short and long SMAs and EMAs are catching up, and MACD is converging for a cross at its bottom out level, so the room for growth is incredible and the push is around the corner. 

All it needs is one burst of buy orders in the next couple days without Wall Street's short volume and the 8.4 million degenerates WSB can be in control again. This is without even mentioning social media influence now that everyone's eyes are on the stock.

&#x200B;

[GameStop Execs sit on $1.3 billion gains](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-29/gamestop-executives-sit-on-1-3-billion-gain-from-trading-frenzy)

[GameStop appoints new execs for Transformation](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2021/02/03/2169124/0/en/GameStop-Appoints-Chief-Technology-Officer.html)

[GME Short Interest by Volume](https://www.marketbeat.com/stocks/NYSE/GME/short-interest/)

[GameStop announces multi-year partnership with Microsoft](https://news.gamestop.com/news-releases/news-release-details/gamestop-announces-multi-year-strategic-partnership-microsoft)

body:

Wednesday option volumes

author: Hambo_
body: This post was amazing, but one question. Do you have any doubts or reasons why someone shouldn't invest in AMD? I think its always good to look at something from both sides and I'm pretty new to investing (and your obviously more experienced than me) so just wondering if you have anything.

author: MrrQuackers
body: Here's where stocks piss me off. I knew about how AMD was going to be killing it with Ryzen and on top of (more importantly) than that, their Epyc server processors were going to destroy Intel's offerings. So I bought a bunch of shares. Then no change, news is everywhere about how AMD is taking market share from intel in computer and server space. No change. They break market share records. No change. It's not until big names like Morgan Stanley and others simply say "uh AMD is a buy now." Then their stock prices start soaring. It's not about the actual value of the business but who tells everyone else to buy or sell.

author: Yessirski1738
body: Bb the next AMD?📈🚀

author: BruceInc
body: WeBull is also at the mercy of their clearing house. Go with a broker that self-clears. Fidelity, TD, JPM, hell even Merrill or Vanguard are all safer bets than WeBull or Tasty Or whatever else. And it doesn’t even matter if you don’t plan on investing into “meme stocks”. Don’t forget that RH limited buys on GM, impossible meats, AMD and even Starbucks. That sort of thing can not be allowed in a free/open market

author: wearahat03
body:
Interesting story.

The real moral of the story: don’t hate rich strangers.

You get rich off aapl, gme, amzn, amd, crowd, plug etc etc?

Guess what? There are billionaires holding those stocks who got way richer.

If you avoid gains because you hate rich people getting richer well you’re not going to get rich.

And you can be damn sure that Wall Street has their finger in every pie.

Look after yourself first. That’s your plan A.

No one cares about your wealth as much as you do, and definitely don’t rely on the people in congress to change the entire system.

author: neoyatzy
body: There use to be a lot of good tips here. I’ve been following Shopify here since it was under 30, AMD since  some asshole yolod 30k of CC debt at 8/share, and I remember when people were talking about how Tesla is going to hit 200. Plays on Microsoft etc. now it’s like these shit penny stocks and some dream of some crappy gaming company on it last leg turning around. Don’t try and catch a falling knife. I learned that here and now all these tards are doing the opposite? Why? Bc hedge funds? Who gives a fuck about hedge funds we’re here to make some money and learn. This place isn’t about fighting the man. This place is about greed.

author: thalesolivepress
body: I got in AMD at average $2.50 a share. Sold it later at $11.50 a share. Thought I had made out like a bandit, paid off some debt with it and that was that. Take it from me, patience is golden.

author: ABonafidePotato
body: I also bought into TSM the last week. I'm very bullish on them and AMD and think this is the perfect dip to buy for the long term.

author: ennuiday
body: Got a couple other twinkles in my eye, but yes probably.  Going to be tough to get excited over AMD earnings after GME.

author: donktastic
body: I think 85 is a great buy point for AMD. AMD and Intel trade off every few years so even though AMD is the hot pick, I would snag a few of INTC on pull backs also to hedge future bets, anything less than $50 on iNTC is buy territory for me.

author: OhWowMuchFunYouGuys
body:
Absolutely correct, you should be treating everything as a sales pitch. Nobody is putting in the work to do that research just to help you for nothing you can guarantee they have a position or they are thinking about it trying to gauge the room.

Be smart, if you see something report it. Dm me directly if needed. I know you guys want to preserve the subreddit and part of that is going to be on your shoulders of reporting and bringing to light the things that are malicious.

We do everything we can amd you can help us do more to keep this place great.

author: HandoAlegra
body: Also buy TSMC (NYSE:TSM) (the manufacturers for AMD). They're prices more-or-less were the same through 2020, but in Q4, TSM flew past. This is in part to Intel announcing partnership with TSMC.

author: jcarmona24
body: Man who else has been here since 2016? I miss the days of betting on AMD at $4-$6.  This sub has came along so far

author: GundiScheme
body: I got in around $40 and I am holding with my fingers crossed. It seems like they are competitive with NVIDIA and NVIDA's stock price is insane. Intel has made too many mis-steps and they have a lot of dead wood stifling innovation. So I think AMD is a good way to invest in this space...try to get in as low as you can good luck

author: Potential_Shoe_9079
body:
The stock is GME. Not BB, not Silver, not AMD, or SNDL. Ape alone weak. Ape together stronk.

💎🚀💎🚀💎🚀💎🚀💎🚀💎🚀 

This is not financial advice.

author: reddinator01
body: So basically, as of right now don’t buy AMD long term buy Xilinx instead and wait for the shares to convert.

author: adjustable_beard
body:
Thats BS. Intel might be a bit behind at the moment but their CPUs are far from POS. 

On top of that, intel has its own fabs so intel will more directly benefit from the EO than AMD which doesnt have any fabs.

body: Amd and SNDL love those stonks!  To the moon SNDL hopefully makes $4.20 by eow!

author: cloudone
body:
As someone who owned $AMD from $2 days I think the company is in more danger than ever.

When the stock was $2, the only competitor was Intel, which was fine because Intel and AMD always traded blows.

Now there's Apple M series, Amazon Graviton series, Pingtouge's XuanTie series, upcoming Microsoft CPU, and who knows what Google has up their sleeves.

author: Secret_Notice
body: Meh... Huge fan of Nvidia. But it's really high right now. And they're a lot of problems getting these new chips out and sketchy ARMs details. I moved away from Nvidia and took a win. Bought AMD instead. But... I will buy again if I see a nice entry point. Prob somewhere in the high 400's.

body: It wasn't really a surprise that their earnings were what they were. Do not let the gme hysteria get to you, amd has a real opportunity to steal some market share from Nvidia, give it time. Amd is a long term hold (for me).

I don't agree with the Robinhood story because of them including AMD (yes a 100b blue chip) in the 'volatility list' so you can only buy 1 share (been at 80-90 for over half a year). 

Hedgies liquidated AMD to cover GME, Robbing the hood just so happened to determine AMD 'volatile'.

author: manitou202
body:
Hey guys, I know it was a shit day for many. But I want to highlight that SPAC's can offer a lot of protection from selloffs if you have the appropriate mix of SPAC's.

6-12 months ago I would have had a really bad day with ARKK, AMD, BABA, and a ton of other tech stocks that I was heavily invested in. 

Instead in my brokerage account which is 100% SPAC's I'm green. If I pull out the gain from CCIV, I was still up 0.5%. I have my investments spread across 15-20 SPAC's at any time, in a mix of warrants, units, and commons. Some are close to NAV, some are more speculative (GSAH), and some are post DA (THCB). 

Overall, I'm really happy how well my account held up on a day like today. Yes you can have tremendous gains if you go all in on only a few SPAC's, but you can do quite well by spreading out the risk.

Thanks again to this community for all of the knowledge!

author: Meymo
body:
As a person who focuses exclusively on buying baskets of individual stocks, I say this to you: You need to focus on quality portfolio construction. In the end, quality always matters. As a part of my framework, I allocate roughly 5% of my portfolio to purchase speculative stocks which don't yet meet my criteria for a core position in my portfolio. Speculative plays include things like IPOs, SPACs, etc. They can also include items like Gamestop, AMC or Blackberry. 

Having a dedicated allocation of your portfolio to take on these items offers multiple benefits:

1. If the play finds support at zero, its a maximum of 5% across my account.

2. Since this 5% total is between any of my new or speculative stocks, it limits exposure overall (e.g. a blend of GME, AMC, BB, + CCIV, IPOE) limits your risk as opposed to dedicating all 5% to one play.

If a speculative item does well and I start to gather more data to support my position on it (e.g. understand what the company is actually doing/their roadmap, their customers/contracts, and sector risks; hard data/math: volatility, geometric mean, Sharpe/Sortino ratios) I consider adding it to my core portfolio (purchasing more and elevating it out of "speculative" status). 

Once added to my core portfolio, it becomes something that I purchase on a regular cadence (e.g. every pay period I purchase my core portfolio). 

Risk management takes incredible discipline, but having a strategy and sticking to it (until something materially changes with your strategy to warrant changes) will give you the best results in the long-term, especially if you're buying individual securities. 

Good luck

author: Astrosalad
body:
I don't know whether this price is good or anything, but I personally would be wary of any long-term investments in SPCE. Sure, they've got hype and good press, but their business is not set up to be competitive in the space tourism sector. Air launch is expensive and a fair bit of hassle, meaning their tickets will be very high price. It may seem at the moment that they're close to launching paying passengers, but let's look at their competitors 3-5 years down the line. You have SpaceX with both Crew Dragon (just announced their first all-civilian flight) and Starship (coming soon™️, but will have huge implications for space tourism), as well as Blue Origin, which is less ambitious but about in the same product slot as SPCE. Both of these companies have huge financial backing and are on track to have significantly lower costs, higher launch cadence, and better product. SPCE may have a small niche somewhere in that market, but I don't think long-term it is a good play.
Source: am space nerd. 

Disclaimer: not financial advice, no position in SPCE
